title: A question about the assassin rework
body: Are champions who can be played as assassins but are mainly bruisers or fighters such as Vi or Zac going to be reworked? Also, is there whole kit going to be reworked or just the numbers?

replies.body:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/Tnfw1WW6-next-class-update-the-assassins here's the list. Also here's the champions being changed

Quick clarification here - this is the list of champions we're considering changes to, not a list of champions that are getting changes. At the very least we won't be making major changes to everyone listed there. 

Because assassins have been a problematic class for years it's also likely we'll end up doing slightly fewer bigger updates this time than with mages and marksmen (so less than 6).

Edit: Poor phrasing on my part there. What I think's likely here is that we do a smaller number of updates this time, with the updates we do do being bigger than average (more work needed per champion).

I don't understand? if the assassin class has been problematic for years, shouldn't you strive to solve these issues with a class update? I mean the size of the project is adequate in order to solve these but you won't tackle them all?

We'll be putting the same amount of resources in as with other class updates. We think each individual champion's likely to be a bigger than usual project though to do well. Might have to do fewer champions as a result.
So it might be a Big 4 this time instead of a Big 6?
Correct. Though they might be a "Bigger 4." Think Vlad/Graves scope with 2-3 abilities changed for all the projects. Not sure if this will 100% be the case or not, it's just the current thinking.

Maybe testing on multiple champion roots while in the jungle if his ult is on might work? Just some thoughts.

Hey KeevalRoy,

First off, sorry that you feel we don't listen or ignore the player base. Not sure when player labs first started as they were already going on for all champions when I joined Riot, which was around when the Marksmen update happened. I know we did player labs on all the marksmen though,

To answer your questions on the champions above I feel like I have to give a little context into how we gather data and analyze which champions were successful or not, even if it will be a little hard to hear, since it seems you really didn't like many of the recent updates. 

Aside from the player labs that happen while in development we also gather a ton of data from the playerbase after a champion rework is released. We gather what we call "Targeted" and "Untargeted" data from surveys that go out to the player base. What do these mean?

"Targeted" - Survey to players that play that Champion

"Untargeted" - Survey to anyone that plays LoL

We ask many questions on the surveys regarding Gameplay, Art, Narrative, Theme, Overall Feelings.

For example, while some people on these forums didn't like the Taric changes, Taric had our highest "Targeted" and "Untargeted" scores of any rework ever done by the Champion update team. In fact, his "Targeted" scores were much higher then his "Untargeted" scores which means that most Taric mains were very happy with the rework,

These go out to a much larger portion of the playerbase then are on the forums. It also goes out to all regions, NA/EU/China/Korea/Brazil. While I believe that the players on these boards opinions and thoughts are super important (it's why I spend a good amount of time on the boards,) I think it would be unfair to say that the players that do go on here and post represent the entire player base for a certain champion.

I do realize this is a super quick rundown of how we gather data, if you have any more questions about this process feel free to ask and I will answer as best I can (Not directly on the Insights Team which is the team that gathers our data, but can answer to the best of my knowledge.)

Anyways on to you questions about Champions above

{{champion:114}} 
Fiora was interesting in that contrary to posts on the boards, Fiora's gameplay changes were very well received, it was her art changes that were more mixed. She also received very high scores in theme, as players thought her gameplay much better reflected a duelist/fencer.

{{champion:98}} 
Shen was actually the opposite of Fiora. Players were very happy about his Art, but less so about the gameplay. Overall the gameplay scores were still higher then pre-rework Shen they just didn't go up enough for how much work went into it. His thematic scores however weren't very great which is why you see us saying we didn't quite hit his thematic well when we post about Shen on the boards.

{{champion:41}} 

Actually, {{champion:41}} {{champion:44}} {{champion:78}} &{{champion:14}} , where all by far our highest rated reworks we have ever done. This is sentiment from Mains and Non-Mains. This data, mixed with the data from Fiora and Shen is part of the reason we stopped doing medium scope projects and started focusing mainly on the full VGUs, as when we put full resources/time into a project it usually goes very well, were the medium ones are pretty hit/miss.

{{champion:104}} 
Graves was actually one of our highest rated roster projects ever

{{champion:82}} & {{champion:72}} 
These 2 were pretty lateral when it came to sentiment from the larger player base. They really didn't go up or down. When it comes to data like this we don't regard them as a success because one of our goals is to improve the champion, not move it laterally. The 2nd goal of roster is to diversify the roster and add more unique gameplay to each champion, so while they didn't go up in sentiment we do think they became a bit more unique then before.

{{champion:133}} 
Quinn actually started out with pretty mixed results. Her gameplay scores went up very slightly, but not down. After a couple months however her gameplay scores went up significantly, which means either new players started maining her and liking her a lot or old players got more used to her kit and ended up enjoying it more.

{{champion:69}} 
Initial Cass reaction was low, but this was partly due to her being on the weak side on launch. In fact, when her changelist leaked early even the sentiment on the boards was super positive to her changes, this changed of course when she was released super weak. After her buffs her sentiment went up quite a lot and it looks like players are enjoying her much more now.

{{champion:161}} 
Vel'koz was the example were the boards and the data matched up. Players on the boards AND a large majority of Vel players didn't really like the update. We actually did bring a bunch of mains in the play the new Vel'koz and he was surprisingly one of the best received by Vel'koz mains during out internal player labs. I think that came from the idea of true damage on the Ult sounding better then it actually ended up being. We also don't have final tuning/numbers when we do player labs so he could have been slightly overtuned. What's interesting is the players during the player labs actually said they liked the kit but that they wanted us to change more, not less. Most players said they wished we completely changed his W into something else. Anyways, as you saw though we did make bigger changes to Vel'koz based on that data. As to weather we should have actually changed Vel'koz more, or not worked on him at all, I'm still not sure which was the right answer. In retrospect I believe we should have skipped him and spent more resources on Brand, which while I think turned out pretty good, could have been even better with another fully reworked ability (Maybe R?)


Anyways, hope this answered some of your questions. I know at the end of the day if you didn't really like a rework it's not going to matter to you if many other people did like it. Wanted to be as transparent as possible with this though.

How is the Zyra update received by mains? Do you separate data for mid vs support?

Vlad and Zyra were actually our highest rated reworks for the mage update, from mains and non-mains. We actually don't separate mid vs support but it is a good point and we probably should in the future.

Thanks for the reply. Since you're here, I want to tell you something that's very important to me that I feel Riot is not taking very seriously.

During the Zyra preview, y'all said she would be balanced as a support. That was revised to balancing both equally. 

When the finished product released, my first impression was that it was a massive buff to supp Zyra since she relies on poke/zone. Zyra mid would suffer since she relied on direct spell damage (nerfed) with a dps component (also nerfed) in a reliable burst combo (also nerfed) typical of AP carries. That ended up being true.

The thing about Zyra mid vs. Zyra bot is that Zyra bot benefits exponentially more from passive seeds than Zyra mid. Her job is to poke, zone, and create engage opportunities for the ADC. Random seeds create more openings for her to do her job. W seeds are strongest for engage but also carry the highest risk. 

Zyra's damage has always been balanced around the risk of being 700-ish units from an enemy while being glassy and immobile. The passive seeds remove that risk while still getting the job done in the support role. That is why Zyra sup is too strong right now.

Mid Zyra's job is to kill things as a carry. Right now she's good at laning, but her burst combo is weaker and totally reliant on plant damage. The passive seeds are not reliable for kill combos. You need the seeds from your W unless you're counter-engaging. Since the rework, spell damage is lower, Q is harder to land, W cooldown is longer, we have to build more CDR, and we need 3 plants to match our old 2-plant damage. Basically, we traded reliable burst for RNG steady poke, which naturally favors support Zyra.

**The point** is that a nerf to the W cooldown disproportionately harms mid Zyra while the rework as a whole disproportionately harmed mid Zyra and benefitted supp Zyra. 

If you want to balance her for bot, you need to hit the passive harder at early levels or add passive cooldown scaling to ranks in W. If you want to balance her for mid, you need to revert the W nerf.

If you tie the passive spawns to W max, you create room to add base damage back to her spells without making her OP. Then you have three distinct approaches to the character:

Q>E max for burst with much fewer but more strategic plants
E>W max for control with much fewer plants early
W>E max for poke/zone with fewer plants early but rapidly increasing between levels 4 and 9

Ditto what Redfeenix says. I've been so unhappy in League since Zyra's rework, but nobody will talk about her. The "I hear you/I'll pass it on" goes a very long way.

It all makes more sense in the context of overwhelmingly positive feedback about her. I guess if you play her bot lane there's a whole lot to like.

A fed Master Yi with an AD/crit (not bruiser) build can insta-delete squishies in less than a tenth of a second with his Q > AA combo, and in less than 0.25 seconds with his Q > AA > AA combo if the first AA didn't kill them. You have to remember that some assassins are so broken that Riot need to give them VGUs in order to properly fix them. They may only get to 4 big assassin updates in this group update, which will leave some problem children still in a bad spot, but Riot will get around to them individually in VGUs. They've already confirmed that they very much want to give both Evelynn and Akali full VGUs, so it's OK if their issues aren't fixed in the assassin update and they focused on the others instead. If they gave full reworks to those two champions, gave group reworks to let's say Kat, Talon, Rengar and Kha'Zix, plus small updates to Zed, Fizz and anyone else, you'd have a pretty comprehensive improvement in the assassin class eventually. 

The good thing about assassins is how few of them there are. Even if you assume every assassin needs a rework, they can all be got around to comparatively quickly. The mage update by contrast left so many champions untouched despite being huge.

If they do rooster updates they do to avoid VGUs.

It does not mean they won' t get a VGU, because **everyone** will eventually get one including already updated champions, it just means that they have to step harder gameplay-wise to fix them. Plus, being a rooster update, allows them to do so coherently and to not step on each other' s toes.
